studies.title: The Influence of Ceiling Height: The Effect of Priming on the Type of Processing That People Use
studies.finding: Higher ceilings promoted abstract, relational processing while lower ceilings promoted detail-oriented processing. Published in Journal of Consumer Research. This study is foundational for understanding how ceiling height affects cognition, though it examines absolute height rather than sequential compression-release.

examples.description: Frank Lloyd Wright's iconic house uses low-ceilinged entry sequences that compress visitors before releasing them into the main living spaces with dramatic cantilevers and expansive views. The entrance hallway is notably low, making the living room feel more spacious.
examples.source: Architectural documentation of Fallingwater; widely cited in Wright scholarship but I cannot verify specific sources without web access

examples.description: The relatively modest entrance portico transitions to the vast domed interior (43m diameter), creating one of history's most celebrated compression-release sequences. The experience of emergence into the rotunda is heightened by the constrained approach.
examples.source: General architectural history; unable to provide specific verifiable source

examples.location: Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth, Texas
examples.description: Louis Kahn designed low entrance galleries that open into the main vaulted gallery spaces, using the contrast to enhance the sense of arrival and spatial drama.
examples.source: Architectural documentation; specific citation unavailable without web search
